sourceDesc.bibl: Turnbull, Gavin,Pastoral Elegy, on the Death of Mr Robert Fergusson., in Poems, (Dumfries, 1794), 28-30.

head.title: Pastoral Elegy, on the Death of Mr Robert Fergusson.11 First published in Poems (1794), pp. 28-30; reprinted in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 21, 1796). Radcliffe comments, the “five double-quatrain stanzas are part of the series imitating John Cunningham’s "Elegy for William Shenstone” (Spenser and the Tradition).

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Why hangs on yon willow the lyre,
Which erst by the Muses was strung?
To which, what themselves did inspire,

Sweet notes were by Fergusson22 Robert Fergusson (1750-1774). Many of Fergusson’s poems in the Scots dialect appeared in Walter Ruddiman’s Weekly Magazine, or Edinburgh Amusement (1768-1773). Turnbull cites Fergusson’s “Braid Cloth” (1771) in his “To a Taylor with Cloth for a New Suit” published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 188-190. sung:
Why droops the blyth lark in her nest?
Ye lambkins, why bleat ye so sore?
Ye shepherds, why are ye distress’d?
Alas! the sweet Bard is no more!
On Fortha’s green banks,33 The River Forth flows west to east from the eastern slopes of Ben Lomond to the Firth of Forth and the North Sea. where the swain
First carroll’d his pastoral song,
The Naiades,44 Water nymphs. dejected, complain
As they glide the sad vallies along.
The wind that howls over the heath
Bids the woods the disaster deplore;
And the grottoes, responsive beneath,
Repeat, “the sweet Bard is no more!”
The Genius of Scotia was glad,
Though her Ramsay55 Allan Ramsay (1686-1758), the Scottish poet for whose play The Gentle Shepherd Turnbull wrote a prologue. was laid in the ground,
When she smil’d on the heav’n-favour’d lad,
Who once more should her beauties resound:
Now, reclin’d o’er the rude rocky steep
Where the billows hoarse murmuring roar,
Her tears falling fast to the deep,
She laments that the Bard is no more!
Though wealth never dwelt in his cot,
Though grandeur was never his care,
The little that fell to his lot,
With his friends he could willingly share.
Mirth still at his banquet was found,
He delighted each guest with his lore;
Who, now pensive sit weeping around,
And lament that the Bard is no more!
Arise, his companions so true,
And wipe from your eyes the sad tear;
With garlands of death-loving yew
Adorn our young Fergusson’s bier:
Behold! where he joins a bright throng,
The honey-tongu’d Poets of yore,
And his name shall remain in the song,
Though the Bard, the sweet Bard, is no more!
